subject: RE: [junit] Re: How to test private methods in a class.
msgSnippet: ... Might sound that way. In my experience, it isn t - the immediate benefits most often are a more expressive and flexible design and simpler tests. Of course
messageBody:
junit@yahoogroups.com wrote:
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Ilja Preuss" <preuss@d...> wrote:
>>
>> A public method is the core responsibility of a class. If we extract
>> a private method, that private method basically provides a service
>> to the public method.
>>
>> It's true that we can remove duplication in a class by extracting
>> private methods. Often, though, if we introduce the right
>> abstraction, we find that the service provided can suddenly be used
>> by other classes, too.
>>
>> Does that sound reasonable?
>>
>
> Sounds more like speculative design and/or rearranging the
> chairs without any clear immediate benefit.

Might sound that way. In my experience, it isn't - the immediate benefits
most often are a more expressive and flexible design and simpler tests.

Of course there are occasions where I can't think of a good abstraction.
Sometimes I try anyway, and either get some insight while doing so, or get
an inferior design. Sometimes I don't do it until the insight comes by a
different way. In any case, I've typically learned something by reflecting
about the private method. Sounds worth the effort to me - your mileage may
vary...

Cheers, Ilja
